This is a model of Bristleback from Dota 2. I've added on the cosmetics requested by a friend. Unfortunately, some of the keys from his necklace are only pictures, not mesh, so I was lazy and deleted them. I should also note that I flattened his feet, so the textures don't map to him perfectly anymore. I hope he'll stand up!  
Pictures and blender files will be on their way soon!  
I've so far only printed him small on a Formlabs resin printer, so I don't know how well he'll work on FDM machines. I do plan on printing him with dissoluble supports.  
I believe that this is the correct model, and there are no problems with it. If you have any difficulties with slicing or printing him, let me know.

I did not design this model, it was taken from Valve's models on the Dota 2 Workshop. The cosmetics were designed by people with much more know-how and creativity than me. I take no credit for it's design. If you're interested in learning how to get these models, you can get the stock models from the Dota 2 Workshop. To turn those models into something printable, follow this guide. Sadly, it is currently not possible to get files out of Dota 2, since the switch to Source 2 engine brought with it a new file format that locks all the models inside. As such, I won't be making any more Dota Models anytime soon. All of my game models are assembled in Blender, repaired with Netfabb (They sponsor the club) and sliced with Simplify3D (they also sponsor the club) and printed in Brandeis University's MakerLab as a member of Deis3D.(The 3D printing club at Brandeis University)

title: Cassette Tape Case with Customizable Logos / Album Art

description.text: Here is an offshoot of my original cassette tape case available here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:647517 This remix adds customizable album art templates. Believe it or not, there is a thriving tape release community among DIY and underground music labels. This is designed to be printed without support structures with a recommended layer height of .2mm. I'm including versions with a rectangular top insert and a round top insert. Print either LogoCassette1RectangulerHole.stl or LogoCassette1RoundHole.stl, then print LogoCassette2 and LogoCassette3. Open LogoCassetteTemplate.skp in SketchUp and customize with your band's album art before printing. I recommend using one color for parts 1 and 2 and another color for the part 3 and the logos. I am only including the pictures of the Pink Floyd Dark Side of the Moon logos as examples of what you can do. I do not own the copyright to that album art, so I can't include it here. (And please don't ask for it.) If you customize or remix this, please list this file as the source and follow the rules of Creative Commons - Attribution - Share Alike. Before attempting to print this, make sure your printer is well calibrated. The parts are designed to fit snugly. I recommend this calibration tool: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:342198/#instructions Big thanks and credit to my friend Austin Gaines for coming up with the idea. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:647517

title: Post drive gear filament guide and fan mount for the Qu-Bd Two-Up or One-Up
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I wanted to be able to print with flexible filament and the Qu-Bd "up" machines have a large open gap between the drive gear and the top of the extruder nozzle, which makes printing with flexible materials impossible. This drop in part solves that problem by providing a tube for the filament to go through. I also bought a fan a while back to prevent overheating of the drive "chamber", which previously caused some disasters, but I had been super gluing it to the side. This part includes a mount for that fan, which you can find here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E37LSE8/ref=olp_product_details?ie=UTF8&me= I just saw the bad reviews, but I must say, my little fan has been truckin' for over a year without a problem. I used an old cell phone charger as the 5v power supply. IMPORTANT UPDATE! I have discovered that, due to the fact that the guide tube needs to be so close to the actual size of the filament, retracting PLA all the way out is nearly impossible. I would recommend AGAINST using this mod with PLA, due to the fact that it plugs up at the end and ends up being wider than 2mm, which will not fit through the hole. If this happens to you, I've had good luck with clipping the filament as far down as possible, then carefully removing the mod with the filament still attached. Flexibles don't seem to plug up at the end like PLA, so they're fine, and I'd venture to guess that ABS would be okay as well. Also, the PLA I printed this with is beginning to show some signs of heat distortion, though not enough to affect its usefulness yet.. I've run a few 3+ hour prints with it and overall it is holding up well. I'd recommend you keep an eye on this and let me know if you have any ideas to remedy it if it becomes a problem.

I printed mine at .2mm layer height and 25% infill with PLA. I recommend you drill out the filament guide hole to provide a smoother surface. Make sure when you print with flexible filament, you keep it SLOW, make sure the first layer isn't too close to the bed, and run it at the appropriate temperature or the plastic WILL back up and find a way to scrunch into the drive chamber.

title: Garage remote control button for GDV 6V3

description.text:
The thin rubber button from the center of my garage remote controls broke so I made a new one from ABS that fits right into the hole.
Unscrew the case, remove any of the old rubber, drop this button in and screw case together. DONE!
Pictures show: 1) the problem 2) the button and 3) the final result.

I first tried making a complete case but that got complex with threads and mount points for the PCB and....
Decided the rest of the case was fine all I needed was a new button over the microswitch on the PCB.
Made a base plate so the button wouldn't fall out of the case and added a curved surface to the top of the button to fit nicely into the look of the existing remote.

title: Pestle and mortar for pills mark 2

description.text:
This is a variant of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:531821
Having used that one for some time I realised that it needed a change that would make exerting significant downward force less 'painful'!
Couldn't think of a way to do this that was readily printable without making the mortar in two pieces which is what this is.
Designed in MOI, made from Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker original.
The screws used were 3mm Button Head Cap Srews 10mm OAL

Because of the forces applied to this I recommend using top and bottom wall thickness of 2.4mm for the pestle (male part) and 1.6mm for the mortar (female part). Then a fill of 20% (in PLA) seems OK.  
And, yes, I realise that I've labelled the part files wrongly. Sorry about that.

Four copies of this part together make
an object, whose surface is called
Roman or Steiner surface (see figure).
For more information see: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_surface (Klein's bottle is mentioned under
"remix" as it might be of interest as well).

The Roman surface also known as Steiner surface
can be described by different equations, see:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_surface Maple 18 offers the new feature to export plots
outputs as STL files - it was used for creating
this object (using the command plot3d and
the equations for x,y,z in polar coordinates). with(plottools)
p2 := plot3d([cos(u)sin(u)cos(v)^2, sin(u)cos(v)sin(v), cos(u)cos(v)sin(v)], u = (1/2)Pi .. Pi, v = 0Pi .. .5*Pi, grid = [144, 144]) # output size limited to 1 MB, at least in academic version
stlp := "............stl"
exportplot(stlp, p2) Important hint: If you want to create and print
your own objects, the spherical angles should
be chosen such that no point is generated
twice (e.g. if phi=0..Pi is enough, then it
should not be extended to phi=-Pi..Pi).
Otherwise no useable .gcode could be created
by the 3d printer software.

description.text:
RO bot SCO ut - Small (relatively) Arduino Powered rover featuring 1-piece Printed ABS treads. MAJOR UPDATE
New Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:145577
New Design Utilizes Android 3.0+ Device for Camera/Wi-Fi Remote control (Telepresence) More Details at http://www.Arxterra.com Design intended to incorporate DC motors (propulsion), servos (for look up/down), and stepper motor (for look left/right), IR sensors (distance ranging), laser pointer (for coolness), shaft encoders (for speed detection/DC motor syncing), gyroscope (for automated missions), XBee control (for guided missions), and a mini-video camera (for coolness). I designed this as part of a school project, replacing a purchased metal chassis/kit with a fully 3D printed (as much as possible) body kit. Suggestions for Improvement Welcome.

Print out a Chassis, a set of wheels, some treads and add a lot of vitamins. PART LIST (links to my sources to come) Essential Vitamins:
1x Arduino Uno (or Mega, but you'll have to drill some holes and shuffle some pin assignments, but you won't need the NANO)
1x Arduino NANO (unless you use a Mega)
1x Adafruit Motor Sheild
2x DC motor w 90ÃÂÃÂ° gearbox
1x stepper motor
1x Dagu Mini Pan & Tilt kit
1x 700mAH 7.2V NiCd battery
1x charger for NiCd battery
1x battery adapter for NiCd
2x shaft encoders
2x Tiny Breadboard
2x rechargeable 9V battery
1x Charger for 9V battery
2x battery clip for 9V
2x right angle barrel connector (center +) for 9V ->arduino/camera
2x DPDT mini switch
4x 1x6 female header
2x 1x8 female header
1x 16 pin IC socket M3x8 hex socket screws
M3x16 hex socket screws
M3 nuts
Breadboard jumper wires
2x 2N2222 NPN BJT transistors
2x 22K resistor
2x 4.7K resistor
2x 1K resistor
2x 10uF capacitor (polarized)
2x 47nF capacitor
2x 10nF capacitor Sensors:
1x Long Range IR sensor
1x Midrange IR Sensor
1X Laser pointer
1x Gyroscope
1x Current Sensor
2x XBee modules
1x XBee USB side
1x XBee Robot Side
1x mini camera w/ receiver Nice Supplementals:
2x clip-on heatsinks
1x extra h-bridge
1x extra 595 shift register
2x extra shaft encoders
2x 1x8 Thru pin female headers
2x 1x6 Thru pin female headers
Assembly instructions for the printed parts to come. I /am/ still in classes right now. This bot is for one of them and we still haven't got all of the systems working smoothly yet. Print Hints
The chassis
This piece is likely to be one of the longest, most arduous, heartbreaking prints you'll ever do. I'm working on a design that will decrease the print time but this version is anywhere from 10 hours (.33mm layer height on my prusa2) up to 17 hours (.2 layer height on my machine). Because it's such a large plate, I suggest having your bed be a little warmer (I set mine to 62C for PLA) and print at a slower speed (all my Slic3r speed settings set to ~30mm/sec, travel @130mm/sec). I also have to print without any skirts on my 185x180 print area. My next chassis design may be just a bit smaller to make it easier to print. The braces (2x brace B and 1x brace C) screw to the underside of the chassis and add some rigidity. They also hold the larger motor battery in place on the underside. The Wheels
It's probably a good idea to print all four wheels at once. They fit nicely on my print area. The DC motors connect to the front wheels via the "Drive Wheel Adapter". The adapter attaches to the inside of the wheel prior to attaching the wheel to the DC motor.
The back wheels use the shaft of the shaft encoder as an axle. If you don't want to use shaft encoders you can use any 6mm dia. bolt/rod as an axle but you may have to round out the hole in the wheel. The set screw should hold the wheel to the axle either way. If the wheels wobble as they turn it's okay as long as they wobble too much and the treads fall off. It's only happened once so far to me, but adjusting the wheels fixes it. The Track
IT IS VERY IMPORTANT TO PRINT THE TRACK USING ABS. PLA won't work. I tried. It's not flexible enough. I made a test using the original track (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15528) using PLA but it broke after playing with it for less than half an hour. ABS is super bendy and it really takes an effort to make it fail. I've been running on the same set of treads for a few hours a week since early February. They still have their flex and snap. The treads should be slightly narrower than the grooved section of the wheels. Everything Else
All the other prints are pretty straight forward. I even included some sample gcodes that I used to print the parts in the appropriate sets. The gcodes are sliced at .33mm layer height at a moderate speed that seems to work for all of our printers here at school.
Remember, FURTHER ASSEMBLY INSTRUCTIONS TO COME

Ever been on the road, and saw your phone, ipad or tablet was getting flat? Then in a fit of mad passion you purchase an off-the-shelf charger, and race back to your car - only to find the damn thing was too short to make contact with the rearmost contact of the socket? In a fit of madness you shove a ball of foil down the back, hoping it wont short out - dammit! blew the fuse!!! well, try printing one of these - and put a 5mm stainless bolt through it. it should help reduce some frustration. 20mm diameter - 6mm thick.
if you need different dimensions, leave a comment and I'll zing it up in a jiffy! (and yes I'm already mad from experiencing as similar event - except i have 5 sockets.)

description.text:
The prusa i3 screwdriver has been designed for my bq prusa i3. It fits on the little screws that are used for leveling the printing platform.  
Why don't i use a normal screwdriver? Because when you are leveling the platform the extruer position is too near to these screws so with a normal screwdriver you can't regulate the height .  
If you print the screw driver and the head of the screwdriver does not fit correctly don't worry, you only need to take out one of the screws heat it a little bit with a lighter or a welder and then make fit the head of the screw driver in to the head of the screw, wait a few seonds and you must have a perfect screwdriver.

title: Drogerdy - Raspberry Pi Controlled Tank Bot

description.text: The second prototype out of the jRobot project, this little tank bot makes use of a number of simple parts to do a whole lot. I have updated it to make it more versatile. The tracks are a little more grippy as well! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJIx0cyOL3s&feature=youtu.be The jRobot project allows my students to dock their Raspberry Pi with any of the robots, plug it all in and program away. The sample build shown makes use of the MCP3008 ADC to allow the RPi to access a range of analogue sensors including the Sharp 2Y0A02 Infrared distance sensor. It has the same pin based docking system as the Apogee Robot (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:648394)

Demo Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MJIx0cyOL3s&feature=youtu.be You'll need 26 tracks per side. The tracks are joined by 35mm long 2mm stainless steel pins. (The same pins are used to hold the RPi in place. Each track assembly will need: 2 x Cogs; 2 x Inner Cog Brackets; 2 x Outer Cog Brackets; and 1 x Track Mid Frame (I am yet to test the improved inner frame) The two track assemblies are then joined by 2 x body parts. The motors must be installed before the body parts are glued together. I glue the whole thing together using 5 minute epoxy. Some one a tip of each stainless steel rod is also helpful to stop the tracks from falling apart. The motors fit the cogs directly and are no-name yellow geared ones that you get on eBay (http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1pcs-Anti-interference-f-Robot-Smart-Car-Chassis-DIY-DC3V-6V-DC-Geared-Motor-TT-/291314517942?pt=AU_B_I_Electrical_Test_Equipment&hash=item43d3b2c7b6) The motor contoller in the same bot is an L298N board which fits perfectly in the bottom of the tank body. ( http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1pcs-Anti-interference-f-Robot-Smart-Car-Chassis-DIY-DC3V-6V-DC-Geared-Motor-TT-/291314517942?pt=AU_B_I_Electrical_Test_Equipment&hash=item43d3b2c7b6 Their are 4 x 5mm holes for LEDs and a square hole that allows for a sensor bracket and cable access. I use a Step Down Buck power regulator that has a USB output to power the Pi - while the motors run straight of the battery. This does mean that the Pi will restart when the batteries run low. I use 2 x 9V rechargbles (500mAh each) which allows for a good 30+ minutes of run time. I use an Adafruit perma proto quarter size breaboard for the breakout board and use header pins so that my students can use jumper cables to wire it up. The sensors are up to you, but I am using two sharp infrared sensors on the one shown that run through an MCP3008 ADC and interface with the RPi via the SPI bus. I also have a light sensitive resistor on it and plan to add a sensor at the rear and one facing down to stop the robot driving off cliffs. I have plans to be able to extend the length of the track assembly adding a third cog ... but I need to overcome some derailing issues. Believe it or not, the one shown was printed on an Up! Mini as I did not have access to my school's larger printer over the summer break.

comments.text: I'm having some problems.  I used 1.75 filament pieces to assemble the tracks.  The tracks are a tight fit to the cogs (no sag).When I run the motor it locks after a while because the cog indentation misses the track pin. I think my track ended up with a longer (or smaller) distance between the segments. I tried to make the track one segment longer and then it is is very loose but the problem persists.  Is there a way to increase the tolerance or fix the track?
comments.author: flima

comments.text: Sorry to hear you are having problems. I have problems with some filaments and not others and more often on my Flashforge than I do on my Up! Mini.
comments.author: flima

comments.text: I was curious if you had tried chamfering the cog edges just a tad.  Not TOO much, as you of course want plenty of cog.  My track is exactly as you describe, with the 10mm sag (maybe slightly more, but not much) and what appears to happen is that things work fine for a while, but then for a reason I can't quite see, the tread doesn't fall nicely into the cog.  I chamfered one side of the cog (with a knife, because I didn't want to reprint it just yet) and it helped keep this from happening quite so much.  It also helped alleviate some of the sprue issues I was having (I would get some on a few of the treads on the inside).  Anyway, I love the design.  I'm actually going to stick my beagle bone black in there.  I have an old JStamp (If I can develop for it again) I might revive and stick in here as well.  Anyway, really cool, and simple.  I used panelling nails for the treads.  Might be easier than cutting up hangars (unless you've got a closet full of them!)  I don't know if you have access to those as easily as hangars.  The first set of treads I printed had some of the holes a little off, so the nails actually did need to be hammered gently, but if the treading is printed correctly (I used the one straight from the track.stl) things work really well.  Thanks again.  I'm looking forward to getting this thing going.
comments.author: timmiclark

comments.text: Yes, chamfering the edges might work.
comments.author: roboknave

comments.text: I saw something like what you are talking about that might work here.  Maybe if the teeth were rounded it wouldn't catch.  I think that is kind of what happens.  Since the treads are printed, the .2mm print I used produced the expected striated finish.  I think at some point this tends to grip the teeth of the cog, not letting the round middle part slide nicely in and out of the grooved area in the cog.  That seems to be the real major binding issue.  If it weren't for that, I think this design works pretty well.  I've seen others, some really similar to this, but with the rounded cog design.  When I go to do this again (and I'm eventually hoping to print another one, but one thing at a time), I think I'll look into rounding the cogs.  I did file down the sides and one side of the teeth just a hair, and it does help, but I still eventually get stuck and the tread binds.  The bind isn't quite as strong as it was, so maybe the motor can take care of it.  When they get here.  Last I saw, they were headed for JFK... So hopefully soon.

A simple (parametric) solder fume extractor, with logo: Swansea Hacker-space. Video of it working,
http://youtu.be/HxmKZm0LsUw tested in my local hackers .. http://swansea.hackspace.org.uk/ With an activated carbon filter, this will remove all those nasty fumes. I got the filter from Mr. Spongess !! http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/1-x-Sheets-Carbon-Aquarium-Fish-Tank-Filter-Sponge-Foam-Pond-12-x-9-/121534085028? The OPENSCAD file will work for 40, 50, 80 and 120 mm Fans. More Photos & a Video to follow. I will add a proper mount for the cable/power inlet soon.
Possibly a speed controller, - but MY 120 mm fan is totally quiet - so will leave at 100%. My Kids want a minecraft one, so I will probably oblige next week.

My first print, since mid of November, the black 120 fume extractor,
Bad settings, and even worse, I ran out of filament - boo hoo :(

Edit the OPENSCAD file,
Choose fan size (0..3) for 40,50 80 &120 mm) Check Th_Fan and XY_Fan, are correct for your fan !! Note, I added 1.5 mm to XY_Fan, to allow for my printer,
because I used 0.8mm extruder. Also Adjust Box_Wall, to give solid walls, (1.5 - 1.6 for mine) Print,
Fit Fan,
Cut a piece of filter material .. Slightly over sized.
Push in, 1-2 mm inside of Solder away.

description.text:
The entire printable catalog of parts for the 2D Cross Section models. The Truncated Cone Circle is sectioned into 3 parts, with the cross sections of the faces generating a circle and a hyperbola. The Truncated Cone Ellipse is sectioned into 3 parts, with the cross sections of the faces generating an ellipse and a parabola. The Truncated Cube 3 Piece is sectioned into 3 parts, with the cross sections of the faces generating a diamond and a pentagon. The Truncated Cube 4 Piece is sectioned into 4 parts, with the cross sections of the faces generating a trapezoid, a hexagon, and a triangle. Print out 9 copies of the snap-fit peg. Pegs are snapped into the follow parts:
Truncated Cone Circle - parts A and C
Truncated Cone Ellipse - parts A and C
Truncated Cube 3 Piece - parts A and C
Truncated Cube 4 Piece - parts B and D (note: two pegs snapped into part B)

title: New Technology NYC Subway Train R142 "B" Subway Car

description.text:
I have spent months working on everything to make this subway car right. Its currently in beta testing, so expect a lot of bugs. This is a R142 "B" subway car, you need 6 of these to make a 10 Car R142 Set, or 3 of these to make a 5-Car set. These cars go in the 5-Car set as follows: 1st Car - "A" Subway Car
2nd Car- "B" Subway Car
3rd Car - "B" Subway Car
4th Car - "B" Subway Car
5th Car - "A" Subway Car These cars go in a 10 cars set as follows: (Note: You can make a 2 five car sets and connect them later) 1st Car - "A" Subway Car
2nd Car- "B" Subway Car
3rd Car - "B" Subway Car
4th Car - "B" Subway Car
5th Car - "A" Subway Car
6th Car - "A" Subway Car
7th Car - "B" Subway Car
8th Car - "B" Subway Car
9th Car - "B" Subway Car
10th Car - "A" Subway Car Please be sure to glue the couplers in the correct position so the train can run smoothly without them getting stuck in track curves because the couplers were put on wrong. In order to connect all of these cars you have to print the couplers and connect the end of the coupler to the wheel base and the under carriage, then connect one coupler to the other coupler. In case your coupler came out weak, I recommend to tape them together and that will fix the problem so the coupler dosent disconnect while the train is running. Have fun printing! Coming Soon:
R40 Slant Subway "A" and "B" car.
Subway Stations
Elevated Stations
Subway Tracks for Subway Cars made by me.
Elevated Trestles
And more!

This is easy, you need to follow the instructions for the "A" car but instead of printing the front part of the car, you need to print out 2 of the end car part and replace the steps with gluing the front part of the  car to the base with gluing the end part of the car to the front and back of the car.

description.text: This is a metaCAD script that can generate simple shaft collars with a slot for a nut and a hole for a set-screw.

comments.text:
I just love those parametric things! You've just generated someone an assortment of objects, always including exactly the one someone needs. It highlights the fundamental benefit over manufacturing to stock and (then hoping to be) selling the stock which is usually over or understocked and always unknown. Apart from the fact that it is often not economical for a manufacturer to create too many different sizes/types of a product. A limitation that is evidently not applicable to virtual designs (insignificant amount of megabytes).
This design is especially small (less than one kilobyte) since it's parametric.

A turntable bearing base thing. The retaining clip has no overhang so printing should give reasonable results. I find a bit of ooze tends to create string across the grove so I get the best results by sanding smooth the grooves before assembly. The OpenScad file is included and can be used to generate other sizes or more rings for heavier loads. Unfortunately this was a rapid prototyping exercise so the OpenScad file is minimally documented.
Print the two pieces. Fill the grooves with 6mm BB balls. Press the top half onto the bottom half.

description.text: Design with 0.4mm Default.

A simple set of trays for conveniently holding your boxes of tea! Designed around a a standard box of tea (Bigelow, Tazo, Twinnings...) this set of shelves will keep tea close at hand.   
Print as many shelves as fits your tea collection.

Each tray holds two boxes of tea. Print the desired number of shelves and one each of the wall mount and wall mount mirror.  
Shelves are suspended from kitchen twine. Tie a knot in the bottom of each of the four corner strings and thread the twine through the eyelets in the lowest shelf, so that the knot sits under the shelf. Tie the next set of knots above this shelf and repeat. To hang, tie a final knot above the eyelet in the wall mount after threading the top of the twine through.   
Recommended shelf spacing is 6.5 inches for easy box removal.

I think it well be fine to use printbot to print this design by PLA or ABS.
However I would like to suggest you start to print with 0.2mm layer height, and slow down the speed than 50mm/s, infill can use 10%~30% should be enough, and the shell thinkness use over 2 loops (0.8mm).
And your Build Volume is 6″ x 6″ x 6″ / 150mm x 150mm x 150mm, so you must make sure the model can fit in, or you need to make scale down to fit in.
Hope you will success print this Apollo Astronaut.
Have a nice print :)

author: Kimmiexbollie

description.text:
The gyro designs I saw on the internet were too heavy looking and used a lot of material, so I set out to make one that looked elegant and thin. It had it´s challenges, but after 5 prototypes and a lot of PLA, I arrived at Gyro Air. I don't like supports, so I made every form nice and round. The nipples that worked best are derived from the parametric gyro cube from smorloc By popular demand I have uploaded a smaller version.
https://youtu.be/dMZzUBG6w0s

By popular demand I have uploaded the model in two sizes: 10cm and 7cm. The big one has 5 spheres and the small one has 4. No supporting structure needed.
For better results I recommend printing the Gyro Air at it's original size. Printing it too small will make the circles too thin and it might break. I printed the final object with a 0.25mm layer size.
Once printed snap the conical nipples into place beginning from the smallest working your way up to the biggest.
You can add a drop of oil to the joints so the spheres rotate freely.

comments.text: Your heat bed is too hot! Lower to at least 50 & the curling will disappear. PLA has a low melt temp, & doesn't really need a heat bed at all. If you're printing at 230, you certainly have no issue with adhesion. I'd turn the bed off entirely in your situation. Unfortunately I can't print PLA that hot, I only have 1 fan... I had success with .2 layer, 200deg, 50 bed, 60mm sec, 0 infill, .75 shell, on a Prusa i3 Mk1.
comments.author: lazar89nis

comments.text: I have the same printer as you and I suggest printing a few mods for it.  mine did this a lot as well but I got rid of the injection moulded head and swapped it out for the one micromake listed on thingiverse.  Then I printed a clamp on head cooler (the thing that directs airflow over the nozzle) and it seems to work much better so far.  much better airflow than the stock design.

title: Mounting Bezel for 4D Systems 4.3" Touchscreen uLCD-43PT

description.text:
This was made for the uLCD-43PT specifically, but will likely be compatible with the other two uLCD-43 models... perhaps others that share similar geometries.  
The bezel is also used as a mounting bracket that sandwiches a panel/plate between itself and the LCD using four screws.

• Cut out relief and drill hole pattern in panel where the LCD is to be mounted.
  • Place the LCD on the backside of the panel so that the display pokes through the relief that had been previously cut out.
  • Align the hole patterns on the panel with the ones on the LCD.
  • Run four screws through the underside of the LCD's mounting holes, through the panel, and into the bezel.
  • Once all four screws are started, tighten down to secure in place.

Have you ever wanted to generate your own green energy at home? Well now you can with this hydro-electric project. This is the MK1 version which features a NEMA17-based motor generator, 3D Printed; shaft, chassis and turbine. It is a work in progress that will need a lot of development work in order to optimize the design...but hey it's a start. The idea is to develop a technology which can be attached to small streams, water outlets, pipes and home dams. You will need to add two press fitted 608ZZ bearings. You will also need to bond everything together with epoxy adhesive to make it watertight. Don't forget to visit our site http://www.creationengineering.co.uk for further information on our technology, research and creations. Don't forget to follow us on Twitter @bioprinting2 for further information on creation updates.

title: Headphone Holder for fabric cubicle wall

description.text: This bracket holds up a pair of headphones on a fabric cubicle wall using nothing more than pins to hold it up, and leaving no mark in the cubicle wall when it's removed. It can easily hold up even a fairly hefty pair of headphones. It requires the metal double-pin piece from an Advantus Panel Wall Clip (http://www.zerbee.com/Products/Advantus-Panel-Wall-Clip__AVT75338.aspx) or similar clip (see picture), which will snap onto it, so that the pointy pins can be used to hook into the fabric of a cubicle wall system. If you don't have those, you could probably modify the design to something you can shove push-pins through, or use some other kind of pins, but those clips are pretty ubiquitous in fabric-cubicle-wall offices. It's sized to fit most headphones, including the Sony MA Series comfort headphones I use at work.
When 3D-printing, you will need supports because of the part that the pin assembly snaps over. See the pictures to show how the pins get put into place.

Breakneck Ridge is a mountain along the Hudson River between Beacon and Cold Spring, New York, straddling the boundary between Dutchess and Putnam counties.  
It has several summits, the highest, some distance inland, reaching approximately 1,260 feet (384 m) above sea level. The southern face of the peak is remarkable for its striking cliffs, the result of quarrying in past years.
I used http://jthatch.com/ for the topography, imported it into Simplify3d and printed on a rebranded Flash Forge Creator sold as Micro Center Power Spec Pro

This project came of necessity.  One day I found my 15 month old granddaughter opening the oven door.  The oven is a split design with the oven on the bottom and the grill (smaller oven) on top.  It is built-in to the kitchen base units.  The latch is installed on the lower edge of the top oven door with the slide piece sitting below the top of the main oven door.  Rotating the top piece of the latch lifts the slide to allow the oven door to open.  Releasing the top piece lets the slide drop back into its locked position.  When the oven door is closed again the slide rides up over the top of the door and locks behind it.  For times when the oven door is frequently opened and closed, rotating the top of the latch fully clockwise locks the slide in the released position.  Future versions will have an interlock to prevent the child from turning the top of the latch fully clockwise without pressing a button on the side.  The latch is stuck to the top oven door with strong double-sided tape or even glued into position.  My prototype has been installed for several weeks now and my granddaughter is yet to dislodge it or open the door.

Print (best quality) the base, slide, plate, top, pin and retainer.  Carefully sand the slide, pin, retainer, top and bottom to make them smooth.  Put the slide in the slot in the base.  Install the spring.  Glue the plate into position above the slide.  The plate fixes in three location, along each side and the pin in the middle. Glue carefully so as not to get the slide stuck.  Here's where there is some variation in the current design to the parts above. In this version it is necessary to glue the Pin to the Top.  The best way to do this is to put the pin into the base and apply glue to the top of the pin.  Lower the top into position but don't push it all the way down.  Leave for a while for the glue to set.  Future versions will have the pin included as part of the top.  When the pin is firmly set, push the top down to leave about 0.5mm clearance to the base.  Glue the retainer to the pin on the underside of the base and leave to set.  Finally stick the latch to the oven door as shown in the pictures.

title: Touch Pi: Portable Raspberry Pi A+

description.text:
http://youtu.be/cwg4JfRPClo In this project we're building a portable Raspberry Pi using the model A+, PiTFT 3.5” display, Powerboost 500C and a 2500mAh lithium polymer battery. We designed this very simple case in CAD - It's a two part enclosure that's fasten together with screws. All the components are panel mounted and fit nicely in a small little enclosure. This is a great starting point to build on top of, because you can modify the parts to fit your project and reuse any components - It's a very modular design and it's open source so you can make it yours. Full Tutorial
https://learn.adafruit.com/touch-pi-portable-raspberry-pi/ Adafruit invests time and resources providing this open source design, please support Adafruit and open-source hardware by purchasing products from Adafruit! Designed by Noe and Pedro for Adafruit Industries.
Creative Commons 2.5, attribution share-alike.
All text above must be included in any redistribution.

Check out the full tutorial on The Adafruit Learning System. Features circuit diagram, assembly photos and full list of materials. Full Tutorial
https://learn.adafruit.com/touch-pi-portable-raspberry-pi/ Featured Components

Ok, this one is kinda meta. Continuing with the theme of making stuff into a set of gears, this is one large gear made of eight smaller ones. I used the involute gear script that was already in the scad file from the Eccentric Sphere Gears script and its predecessors, and made a gear to cut the other gears out of. I basically mashed it up with itself.

Print one center and two of each gear. Gears 1 and 2 are one side (2 of each make up one flat surface) and gears 3 and 4 are the other side. Use 16-18mm M3 screws for the large gears, 18-20mm for the small.

Just a little tool to organize sewing thread spools.  
I made this as my very first thingiverse object for my girl. It measures 210 mm by 152 mm to fit into a box that was lying around.  
Space for 34 spools leaving enough space for your fingers to grip a spool. Spools up to a diameter of 30 mm should fit without problems (even a little larger if you alter spool diameters on neighbors).  
Please take a quick look at the instructions.

Should print in ABS or very good quality PLA. Bad PLA tends to be brittle and it is easy to tear of the pins.  
Print it with a shell thickness of at least 0,8 mm. Thicker if you try your luck with PLA or you want more stability. Top thickness do not matter.  
I printed it WITHOUT the bottom layers, using a nice infill pattern of about 20%. This largely reduces printing time without resulting in a to flexible piece.  
A last warning: Your printer settings should be nearly perfect in terms of stringing and oozing - otherwise you have some work in cleaning the pins.  
I printed this thing successfully rather slow on my Prusa i3 with Orbitech ABS in about 6 hours. Most of the time is for the base plate.

author: FallenXBlade

description.text: Test of Extrudy software.

APA102 LEDs controlled by Teensy 3.1. Variable brightness, delay, and intermission (time between effects) controlled via an android app constructed with MIT App Inventor 2 via blue tooth and an HC-05 Module. Uses the incredible FastLED library. video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p9_Nv5Tiq-Q

Bear with me, I'll be adding supporting documentation as I am able, I just figured I would get this out with apologies... Parts list:
  • Teensy 3.1
  • HC-05 Wireless Bluetooth Transceiver Module
  • 1M 144LED/M APA102 Led Strip
  • Polycarbonate Tubing, 1/2" ID x 5/8" OD x 1/16" Wall, Clear Color
  • "Lipstick-sized" External battery Power Bank 3.5 x 0.9 x 0.9 inches
  • Zip ties or 3.5" 1/4" bolts and nuts for main assembly
    • Software:
  • The Arduino program is attached as "Led_POV_POI.ino".
  • The App Inventor 2 program is attached as "Led_POV_POI.aia" and can be compiled or modified at http://ai2.appinventor.mit.edu
  • "BitMapConverter.zip" is a .Net application used to create byte arrays from bmp files. I am sure there are more efficient ways to deal with images, but this worked fine for the limited scope of my particular project.
    • Assembly:
    As far as the 3D printed pieces, you can see how most of it goes together based upon the pictures. You have a choice of printing out a 1 piece or two piece main body, the advantage of the 2 piece body being that it is more sturdy. The "equilateral_10mm_led_mounting_surface" piece provides a base for mounting the LED strips (mine had 3m tape on the back). I printed out 3 and, after soldering 3 lengths of LEDs together, I stuck them to the pieces. this assembly slips right into the polycarbonate tubing. Wiring for LEDS:
    pin 5 from Teensy to DI (Data in) on LED Strip
    pin 6 from Teensy to CI (Clock in) on LED Strip
    VUSB from Teensy to 5V connector on LED Strip
    GND from teensy to GND on LED Strip
    Use pads on opposite side of microUSB to solder in power Daisy chain GND to GND, CO to CI, DO to DI, and 5v to 5v for the remaining 2 strips. Wiring for HC5:
    Pin 10 from Teensy to RXD on HC-05
    Pin 9 from Teensy to TXD on HC-05
    3V from Teensy to VCC on HC-05
    G (between to p and v) from Teensy to GND on HC-05

title: iPhone 4 or 4s Card Holder Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: You can now buy this case from my Shapeways shop here: http://www.shapeways.com/model/995572/iphone-4s-card-case.html?li=moreFromShop&material=6 An easy to print iPhone case with a slot to securely hold a credit card, driver's license, or college ID. This case protects your phone well because the edges of the case are tall enough to prevent the glass from touching when the phone is placed face down. It also has indents that make it very easy to use the buttons and sliders.

The ledge that holds the case onto the phone has a slight bevel that makes it possible to print without support, as long as low enough layer heights are used.  I printed mine with 0.1 layers, single walls, 40% infill, and 4 solid layers.  You will need support for the card gap.  I had to use a thin saw to cut the support away.  You might also want to scale the print up by 1% to account for shrinking.

title: Black&Decker; Food Processor (from Walmart) Blade Repair

description.text: So, you bought a Black & Decker food processor from Walmart, and the first or second time you shredded cheese with it the hub of the blade stripped out? Yea? Well, you aren't alone. You WILL need to scale this print to fit your particular hub and blade, and it will depend on the plastic you use and your printer calibration. I suggest printing upside down just a few layers to get the scale correct. On my printer, At 100% the new hub will press on the shaft but be loose on the blade. At 110 percent, it will be loose on the shaft and not fit the blade at all. I believe I used 101 or 102% for an easy fit to both, using PLA. Again, using another material like ABS will result in the need for differrent scaling. This is supposed to be a very tight press fit in the blade, yet allow you to turn upside down on shaft to use the other side of the blade. Designed quickly on tinkercad, this worked for me so at this point I have no intention of updating. You are free to do whatever you wish with this part as long as credit for the design is maintained. Use this at your own risk.

description.text:
Keep cats out of the fishbowl with this stylized lid!  The crenelated ramparts discourage snooping felines.   The play in the collar around the lid makes it hard for cats to lift it off (it has to be roughly centered to remove it, which requires more dexterity than most cats have), and the "fortress" facings on either side limit the angle of removal.  
The idea is that humans can easily lift it off the top, but cats will have to push or pry it from beneath, and will not have the leverage combined with the dexterity to remove it.  
The towers protrude enough above the top of the structure that flat objects like books can be safely placed on top of the item without cutting off the air supply for the fish.

• lasercut all the pieces from 3(ish)mm acrylic. There's some play here (sorry, I didn't make this configurable), so the material works up to about 3.3mm.

  • bond the "lid" together using the two square pieces and the four struts arranged diagonally. The grate on the lid is the top and the big hole is on the bottom.

  • bond the lid to the two upright castle-looking thingies. This is very tight even if the materials match, so you may need to (gently!) hammer them together to get them to match up.

  • clamp and wait as directed for your bond directions require.

Want to kill the lights? Simply slide this on your light switch and shoot with your nerf gun. Print at somewhat high infill or it won't last very long.  
As requested i made another design that can turn the lights on and off. this is for the best marksmen. A 3mm set screw slot has been added so that the target is less likely to fall of the switch.

title: Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Wheel 82 mm (iteration 3)

description.text:
Parametric Lego Mindstorms Mecanum Wheel 82 mm (iteration 3). The Mecanum Wheel can be printed without any support structures. Needed Parts for building a single wheel: 16x MecanumWheel3_Roller
1x MecanumWheel3_Left (or MecanumWheel3_Right)
8x Lego Axle 4L (length=31.4 mm, PartNr 3705) Also added are the files with name containing the word "_printable". These files have been slightly modified so that my 3D printer prints them more accurately. The roller's profile has been generated based on following model:
http://www.chiefdelphi.com/media/papers/download/2749 Remark: To build a four wheel robot one needs 2 left wheels and 2 right wheels. It is possible to drive sideways using these wheels The current model is fully printed in PLA. It might be better to print the rollers in Ninjaflex or perhaps paint the PLA rollers with rubber paint to avoid slipping of the wheels. Printing the base of the wheel in PLA is much easier then printing it in ABS. So I recommend using PLA for the base of the wheel. Changes compared to previous design:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:641377
  • the weight of the wheel has been decreased a lot. Printing time is also much shorter
  • the wheel can be used from both sides (at the same time)
  • expected disadvantage is that the wheel will be less stable: the short axle bearing is only 4 mm and only supports the axle in the middle.
    • Depending on how this wheel is being used in a robot, following distance piece might be useful:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:653738 The wheels in action:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YWMyd_zxgvY&feature=youtu.be Final Remarks:
  • although these wheels work as expected, the performance of these wheels is inferior compared to design:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:641377
    The sideways driving, which is the main purpose of these Mecanum wheels, is much better controllable with the latter wheels.

Built to house an Arduino Uno board, a 9g micro servo, and a month's worth of fine grain fish food pushed out using an auger, this automatic fish feeder can be used to feed fish several times a day at varying amounts depending on how you use the Arduino code. It's thick construction allows modifications such as drilling, sanding, and shaving to accommodate different sized servos or other printing imperfections. This system is designed specifically to hang from an aquaponics planter and distribute food to the fish below. See here for version 1: http://helioslabs.blogspot.com/2014/12/3d-printed-auto-fish-feeder.html The code is the same and easily modified. A detailed explanation for this version with more information can be found here: http://helioslabs.blogspot.com/2015/01/arduino-3d-printed-fish-feeder-v2.html Have SketchUp? The files I used before exporting as .stl files and importing into MakerBot's software are now up on SketchUp's 3D Warehouse. Exploded View :: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=u84a55d24-bed0-4b04-aeca-24e8cfb974fe Print Layout View :: https://3dwarehouse.sketchup.com/model.html?id=u4171ad09-6310-4798-bb3d-c867eb701067 Another feeder on Thingiverse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:301532) served as the starting point for this project. Thanks for sharing!

This is the second version. The first version can be seen here: http://helioslabs.blogspot.com/2014/12/3d-printed-auto-fish-feeder.html The first version was very flimsy and required heavy modification (sanding, cutting, gluing of all parts). In all, it worked but just barely. This new design's auger is better suited for pushing out fine grain fish food and the thicker construction made it easy to install the 2mm screws needed to fit it together. Using the low resolution on MakerBot's Replicator 2, produced decent results, but for example, the t-slots for the arms needed to be forced in a bit (very carefully). The auger also required a little modification to fit with the servo.

comments.text: Nice work.  Yours will feed pellets?  The servo motor I used wasn't strong enough to push the pellets.  It would bind up.  What was the torque rating on the servo motor? The servo I used was HK15138 4.3kg @ 6v.
comments.author: coberdas

comments.text: Yes it feeds small 1-2mm pellets. I used a 9g 5V micro servo that came with a SparkFun Arduino starter kit. Initially, my auger would jam as well. The first auger I 3D printed had too little clearance between itself and the shaft. The second one had fewer turns in it and a larger clearance. I also powered my servo separately from the Arduino and this made a huge difference. You can see the differences between V1 and V2 here: http://helioslabs.blogspot.com/2015/01/arduino-driven-3d-printed-fish-feeder.html
comments.author: coberdas

description.text:
When heating up soup or canned meals in the microwave I always covered them with a paper towel to prevent splatter (covering the inside of the microwave with bits of food).
The problem is that many times the paper towel dips down into the food soaking it up and making a mess.
So I designed this to solve the issue. It covers the paper bowls while still allowing hot steam to escape. If the food splatters, just rinse it off in water.

Print solid. Make 2 of the anti splatter file and one handle file (would not fit on my printer in 1 piece. You will need to turn the files 45 degrees if you have a 200mm print area so they will fit.
Once printed, use acetone (for ABS) to glue them together and reinforce the seam with the handle as shown in the photo.

comments.text: Does the plastic not melt in the microwave?
comments.author: mza1979m
